On arrival, the patient is obtunded and appears dehydrated. Temperature is 39.9°C (103.8°F), pulse is 165/min, respirations are 11/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. Examination shows dilated pupils, dry lips, and flushed skin. Bowel sounds are decreased. The patient is unable to cooperate with neurologic examinations. ECG shows sinus tachycardia and a QRS complex width of 130 ms. Supportive therapy with intravenous fluids and supplemental oxygen is begun. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucagon is an antidote for beta-blocker poisoning, which can cause altered mental status and hypotension, both of which are seen here. Additionally, this patient might have had access to beta-blockers because her father has hypertension. However, characteristic ECG features of beta-blocker toxicity are bradycardia (β1 receptor blockade prevents the reflex tachycardia associated with hypotension) and a wide PR interval (due to a first-degree AV block); tachycardia and wide QRS complex would not be expected. Moreover, other features seen in this patient, e.g., mydriasis, hyperthermia, and flushed skin (i.e., anticholinergic effects), cannot be explained by beta-blocker poisoning. Glucagon administration is not recommended in the management of patients with TCA intoxication, as it would worsen the tachycardia.

B) INCORRECT:

Physostigmine can be used as an antidote in severe anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., atropine overdose). While this patient has symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., dry skin), the additional features suggest TCA intoxication. Physostigmine is contraindicated in patients with TCA intoxication because it is associated with an increased risk of cardiac arrest and seizures.

C) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is the antidote for acetaminophen poisoning, which can manifest with nausea, vomiting, and, in the case of acute liver failure, altered mental status. In addition, this patient may have had access to acetaminophen. However, hepatic toxicity typically becomes symptomatic within 24 hours of acetaminophen ingestion and manifests with additional symptoms such as right upper quadrant pain and jaundice. Moreover, the anticholinergic features seen in this patient (e.g., mydriasis, hyperthermia, flushed skin, arrhythmia) cannot be explained by acetaminophen poisoning. NAC is not used in the treatment of TCA toxicity.

D) CORRECT:

TCAs block the fast sodium channels in the myocardium, which decreases cardiac conduction velocity, resulting in prolonged QRS complexes and cardiac arrhythmias. In cases of TCA overdose involving ventricular arrhythmias or QRS complexes > 100 ms, IV sodium bicarbonate is indicated to alkalinize plasma so that protein binding of TCAs (weak bases) can prevent the drug from binding to the fast sodium channels. Additionally, sodium bicarbonate increases the extracellular sodium concentration, which makes the remaining fast sodium channels more active. In patients with TCA overdose, the duration of QRS complexes correlates with the likelihood of developing ventricular arrhythmias and seizures and can, therefore, be used as an indicator of the severity of intoxication. In patients presenting within 2 hours of TCA ingestion, gastric decontamination with activated charcoal can be performed if the airway is established and circulation is secured.

Antiarrhythmics that are typically used in the management of ventricular tachycardia (e.g., procainamide, amiodarone) are contraindicated in TCA overdose because of the risk of worsening sodium channel blockade and/or QTc prolongation.

E) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is the antidote for opioid intoxication. Although this patient has some features of opioid intoxication (respiratory depression, decreased bowel sounds, altered mental status, hypotension) and may have had access to opioids (father has a history of chronic low back pain), she presents with mydriasis instead of miosis, which would be the expected finding in opioid intoxication. Moreover, hyperthermia and wide QRS complexes on ECG cannot be explained by opioid toxicity. Naloxone causes tachycardia and would worsen this patient's symptoms.
questions.hint: This girl presents with features of anticholinergic toxicity (hyperthermia, pupillary dilation, flushed skin, decreased bowel sounds, sinus tachycardia), antihistaminic effects (sedation), α1 receptor inhibition (hypotension), and inhibition of cardiac fast sodium channels (QRS widening), which together strongly suggest tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) intoxication. TCAs are used in the treatment of fibromyalgia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 1-hour history of nausea, dizziness, and confusion. Five hours ago, he told his wife he ingested a handful of pills “to put an end to it all.” He has hypertension, atrial fibrillation, low back pain, and major depressive disorder. His medications are ramipril, metoprolol, acetaminophen, and nortriptyline. On arrival, he is awake but confused. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 100/75 mm Hg. Examination shows dilated pupils and dry, flushed skin. The abdomen is distended, and there is diffuse tenderness to palpation; there is no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. In addition to maintaining a patent airway and administering intravenous fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is the antidote for acetaminophen (APAP) overdose and does not play a role in TCA overdose.

Because APAP overdose may initially be asymptomatic or manifest with nonspecific symptoms (e.g., nausea), this patient should also be managed for potential APAP coingestion. However, in suspected acute, nonmassive APAP overdose, serum APAP level should be measured before NAC administration.

B) INCORRECT:

Sodium bicarbonate is used to counter the effects of cardiotoxic drugs with sodium channel blocking properties, such as TCAs. However, due to the risk of adverse effects (e.g., electrolyte imbalances, alkalemia), sodium bicarbonate is only indicated in patients with TCA toxicity with QRS interval > 100 ms or ventricular arrhythmias. This patient should first be evaluated for cardiotoxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Urine immunoassay is a qualitative test that can be used for screening if the medications of a patient with suspected overdose are unknown. Performing a urine immunoassay is not useful in this patient whose symptoms are most likely due to TCA toxicity. This test would delay another, more important step in management and would not provide additional prognostic or therapeutic information.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucagon is used as an antidote in the treatment of beta-blocker toxicity, which can manifest with neurological symptoms (e.g., dizziness, confusion) similar to what is seen in this patient whose medications include metoprolol. However, beta blockers characteristically cause bradycardia, whereas this patient is tachycardic. In addition, features such as hyperthermia, pupillary dilation, and flushed skin (i.e., anticholinergic effects) are not associated with beta-blocker toxicity. This patient most likely has a TCA overdose, for which glucagon is not recommended, as it would worsen the tachycardia.

E) CORRECT:

In known or suspected TCA toxicity, an immediate ECG is necessary to evaluate for conduction abnormalities (e.g., prolonged QRS, QT prolongation). Inhibition of cardiac fast sodium channels due to an overdose of TCAs can result in cardiotoxicity. The width of the QRS complexes, which corresponds to the likelihood of developing ventricular arrhythmias and seizures, indicates the severity of intoxication. Sodium bicarbonate is used to counter the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs and is indicated in patients with QRS ≥ 100 ms or ventricular arrhythmias. If an airway is established, activated charcoal can be administered within 2 hours of ingestion to prevent further absorption of TCAs. When TCA overdose is suspected but medications are unknown, a urine immunoassay can help establish the diagnosis. This test should not delay further management (e.g., airway establishment, fluid resuscitation, ECG).

To rule out hypoglycemia, measuring capillary blood glucose levels is indicated in all patients with altered mental status. In addition, serum acetaminophen levels should be taken to rule out co-ingestion.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., altered mental status, hyperthermia, tachycardia, pupillary dilation, flushed skin) and alpha-1 adrenergic receptor inhibition (hypotension), which together raise suspicion for an overdose of nortryptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA).

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes for a follow-up examination 3 months after beginning sertraline therapy for major depressive disorder. He takes the medication as prescribed and has started psychotherapy, but his mood has barely improved. The patient appears anxious and reports that he still feels sad and hopeless most of the time. He denies suicidal ideation. He is more tired than usual and often feels drowsy during the day. The patient has difficulty concentrating at work and has missed two important deadlines; he worries that he might soon lose his job. He is also concerned because he has continuously gained weight despite the initiation of sertraline. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 Ib); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. This patient will most likely benefit from switching to which of the following pharmacotherapies?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant that causes sedation. An antidepressant without a sedative effect is necessary for this patient with drowsiness, lethargy, and difficulty concentrating. Moreover, if trazodone is used as monotherapy for MDD, high doses of trazodone are needed for an antidepressant effect and are associated with an increased risk of other side effects (e.g., cardiotoxicity, hypertension, priapism). Trazodone is primarily used in low doses for the treatment of insomnia or as an augmentation agent for the treatment of MDD if the patient has insomnia as a predominant symptom.

B) CORRECT:

The preferred first-line treatment for MDD is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) such as sertraline. Response to the antidepressant is assessed 6–12 weeks after initiating treatment. If the patient has minimal response to the initial therapy or experiences significant adverse effects, the antidepressant should be replaced with a different one by cross-tapering. The class of antidepressants that should be prescribed as a replacement depends on the type of depressive symptoms (e.g., hypersomnia vs. hyposomnia, hyperphagia vs. anorexia, weight gain vs. weight loss) and the side effects from the initial drug (e.g., SSRIs can cause drowsiness, anorgasmia, and decreased libido). This patient has lethargy, difficulty concentrating, and weight gain, and would therefore benefit from switching to bupropion, an atypical antidepressant that has a stimulant effect and is associated with weight loss. Bupropion also does not cause sexual dysfunction.

If the patient has a partial response to the initial antidepressant with minimal adverse effects, then augmentation therapy with another medication (e.g., a different antidepressant, an atypical antipsychotic, lithium, liothyronine) or with psychotherapy should be considered. If the patient has a complete response to the initial antidepressant prescribed for the first onset of a major depressive episode, the drug is continued for another 6–12 months (continuation phase therapy) after which it can be gradually tapered off if the patient remains in remission. Therapy beyond this period (maintenance phase therapy) is considered for patients with a history of recurrent, long-lasting, and/or severe major depressive episodes.

C) INCORRECT:

Aripiprazole is an atypical antipsychotic and can be used as an augmentation agent if the patient has a partial response to the initial therapy. However, antipsychotics are not used as monotherapy for MDD.

D) INCORRECT:

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), such as imipramine, can cause sedation, but also have other significant side effects, including anticholinergic effects (e.g., urinary retention, dry mouth), and are only used in exceptional cases. Switching to an antidepressant with a better side effect profile would be more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

In cases where the patient has minimal response to sertraline, switching to another selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), such as paroxetine, can be helpful. However, this patient is experiencing drowsiness, a possible side effect of all SSRIs. Moreover, paroxetine is an SSRI that can cause weight gain. For this patient, switching to another antidepressant class with a more favorable side effect profile is appropriate.

F) INCORRECT:

The anxiolytic buspirone is used primarily for the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder. There is no evidence to support the use of buspirone as either a monotherapy or augmentation agent in the treatment of MDD.
questions.hint: This patient with major depressive disorder (MDD) shows continued symptoms of depression (e.g., depressed mood, feelings of worthlessness, lethargy, difficulty concentrating, weight gain) and drowsiness (a possible side effect of sertraline) after 3 months of antidepressant therapy. Switching to a different antidepressant that can facilitate weight loss and that is less likely to cause drowsiness should be considered.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes, congestive heart failure, and depression is hospitalized with volume overload and cellulitis on a large area of her right calf. An ultrasound of the lower extremities reveals no evidence of venous thrombosis. She is started on linezolid and levofloxacin for the cellulitis and intravenous furosemide for the volume overload. Her other medications from home (citalopram, lisinopril, and metformin) are continued.
She initially improves, but on her third day in the hospital, her temperature is 40.1°C and her blood pressure is 190/110 mm Hg. On examination, she is confused and has diffuse muscular rigidity.
Which one of this patient's current medications is likely to be responsible for her clinical change?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Furosemide, levofloxacin, lisinopril, and metformin can all cause drug fever or hypersensitivity, but they do not cause the autonomic or neuromuscular findings associated with serotonin syndrome, such as hypertension or muscular rigidity. In addition to causing drug fever or hypersensitivity, these medicines can affect patients in other ways. Excessive doses of lisinopril and furosemide usually cause hypotension, not hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Furosemide, levofloxacin, lisinopril, and metformin can all cause drug fever or hypersensitivity, but they do not cause the autonomic or neuromuscular findings associated with serotonin syndrome, such as hypertension or muscular rigidity. In addition to causing drug fever or hypersensitivity, metformin can exacerbate lactic acidosis and is therefore generally discontinued among hospitalized patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Furosemide, levofloxacin, lisinopril, and metformin can all cause drug fever or hypersensitivity, but they do not cause the autonomic or neuromuscular findings associated with serotonin syndrome, such as hypertension or muscular rigidity. In addition to causing drug fever or hypersensitivity, excessive doses of lisinopril usually cause hypotension, not hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Furosemide, levofloxacin, lisinopril, and metformin can all cause drug fever or hypersensitivity, but they do not cause the autonomic or neuromuscular findings associated with serotonin syndrome, such as hypertension or muscular rigidity. In addition to causing drug fever or hypersensitivity, levofloxacin can induce altered mental status (delirium, agitation), most commonly in older adults.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms are strongly suggestive of the serotonin syndrome, which is caused by overstimulation of 5-hydroxytryptamine receptors in the brain. This potentially life-threatening reaction is characterized by altered mental status (confusion or agitation), autonomic dysfunction (fever, tachycardia, diarrhea, or diaphoresis), and neuromuscular abnormalities (tremor, clonus, or hypertonicity).

The causes of the serotonin syndrome include: (1) Excess precursors of serotonin or serotonin agonists (as with buspirone, L-dopa, lithium, L-tryptophan, trazodone) (2) Increased release of serotonin (as with amphetamines, cocaine, reserpine, fenfluramine) (3) Reduced uptake of serotonin (as with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors [SSRIs], tricyclic antidepressants, trazodone, venlafaxine, meperidine) (4) Slowing of serotonin metabolism (as with monoamine oxidase inhibitors)

Treatment requires immediate discontinuation of the offending agent.

Linezolid is a reversible, nonselective monoamine oxidase inhibitor. Coadministering it with an SSRI can precipitate serotonin syndrome. The Food and Drug Administration has issued a drug-safety communication warning against the use of linezolid in patients taking SSRIs, except for patients with nosocomial infections or in urgent circumstances. If possible, it is best to use an alternative antibiotic because rapid discontinuation of an SSRI can be associated with severe withdrawal symptoms. In addition, the parent drug and active metabolites of some SSRIs have long elimination half-lives that, in some cases, require several weeks before linezolid can be safely initiated.

Key learning point: The antibiotic that can precipitate serotonin syndrome when given to patients taking selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors is linezolid.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman with a history of major depressive disorder presents 6 months after starting fluoxetine. She reports that her mood, concentration, sleep, and appetite have all improved but that her libido diminished shortly after beginning fluoxetine and she can no longer achieve an orgasm. She has no history of hypertension or seizure disorders. She is pleased with the response to fluoxetine and is reluctant to switch antidepressants or change the dose. She asks how the sexual side effects can be treated.
Which one of the following strategies is most appropriate for treating this patient’s symptoms of sexual dysfunction?

choices.text: Wait 3 to 6 more months before making a medication change

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Unfortunately, SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction is often a persistent adverse effect despite attempts to ameliorate it. Therefore, waiting longer without making a change is not likely to resolve the issue.

B) INCORRECT:

Quetiapine can be added to an antidepressant when there is only a partial response to the antidepressant. This patient has responded well to treatment so does not require augmentation. Quetiapine may also induce sexual dysfunction.

C) CORRECT:

In both men and women, the use of selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors is associated with reduced libido, problems with genital arousal, and delayed or absent orgasm. Although the mechanism for this effect remains unknown, serotonin’s dampening effect on nitric oxide and dopamine may be a factor.

Unfortunately, SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction is often a persistent adverse effect despite attempts to ameliorate it. Nonetheless, there are several strategies worth trying. These include lowering the SSRI dose, adding bupropion to the SSRI, or switching from the SSRI to bupropion. The choice from among these strategies should be individualized.

This patient has had relief of her depression symptoms with fluoxetine. Therefore, lowering the SSRI dose or switching to a different antidepressant is not likely to be her first choice.

Adding a second agent may be more suited to this patient’s situation. There is limited, mainly open-label evidence that bupropion can reverse SSRI-induced sexual adverse effects, even when the SSRI is continued. It may improve desire or other aspects of sexual functioning.

Key learning point: The most appropriate approach to treat depression in a patient who develops sexual dysfunction with the use of selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors is to use the medicine bupropion.

D) INCORRECT:

Duloxetine is associated with sexual dysfunction and would not typically be used in combination with fluoxetine because the two medications have a similar effect on sexual functioning.

E) INCORRECT:

Although estrogen clearly has an effect on mood and overall sense of well-being, it is not an effective treatment for depression per se and is not an appropriate choice in this patient‘s treatment.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the emergency room for a persistent painful erection for the last 5 hours. He has a history of osteoarthritis, insomnia, social anxiety disorder, gout, type 2 diabetes mellitus, major depressive disorder, and hypertension. He drinks one 12-oz beer daily and smokes marijuana on the weekends. He takes propranolol, citalopram, trazodone, rasburicase, metformin, glyburide, lisinopril, and occasionally ibuprofen. Examination shows a rigid erection with no evidence of trauma, penile discharge, injection, or prosthesis. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Marijuana use is not associated with priapism.

B) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is a beta-blocker and therefore results in peripheral vasoconstriction. Vasoconstriction would cause erectile dysfunction rather than priapism. Antihypertensive drugs that are associated with priapism are alpha-1 receptor blockers such as prazosin.

C) CORRECT:

Priapism is a potential side effect of trazodone. The exact pathomechanism of trazodone-induced priapism is not fully understood but is most likely linked to the drug's alpha-1 receptor antagonism, which can lead to smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation. Low-flow priapism (LFP), which this patient has, is caused by inadequate venous outflow from the corpus cavernosum and results in painful penile ischemia and a rigid erection. High-flow priapism is usually caused by perineal trauma and leads to a painless, partially rigid erection.

LFP is a urological emergency that requires prompt management. Initial steps consist of aspiration of blood from the corpus cavernosum and intracavernous injection of an alpha-adrenergic agonist (typically phenylephrine). Trazodone should be discontinued in this patient to prevent future episodes of LFP.
Image Description:

In a normal erection, an increase of arterial inflow into the corpora cavernosa's sinusoids makes the penis become rigid. As the pressure builds up, the blood-filled cavernous sinusoids compress venous outflow, maintaining the erection. During detumescence, venous drainage is restored and the erection ends.

In low-flow (ischemic) priapism, blood is trapped within the cavernous sinusoids because of impaired venous outflow (e.g., due to medication, autonomic dysfunction, sickle cell disease), leading to a prolonged, painful erection with completely rigid corpora cavernosa. Increasing pressure within the corpora cavernosa then blocks arterial inflow, resulting in penile ischemia and tissue damage.

In high-flow (nonischemic) priapism, a fistula between the cavernosal artery and cavernous sinusoids (e.g., due to blunt perineal trauma) leads to unregulated, excessive arterial inflow bypassing the protective, high-resistance helicine arterioles. Typically, the corpora cavernosa are not fully rigid or painful, as the venous outflow is intact and there is no tissue ischemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Citalopram, an SSRI, can cause sexual dysfunction such as erectile dysfunction, reduced libido, and anorgasmia. Citalopram does not, however, cause priapism at therapeutic dosage levels.
questions.hint: A sustained erection that lasts for more than four hours indicates priapism.

questions.text: One week after starting a new medication, a 42-year-old woman with depression is brought to the emergency department after collapsing at home. While waiting in the emergency department, she loses consciousness again. ECG shows polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with a sinusoidal waveform. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adverse effects of SNRIs such as duloxetine include sexual disorders (e.g., anorgasmia, erectile or ejaculatory dysfunction, decreased libido), diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, headache, and increased blood pressure. SNRIs do not cause prolongation of the QT interval or torsades de pointes.

B) INCORRECT:

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) such as selegiline are rarely used as first-line or second-line antidepressants because of their adverse effects, which include dry mouth, gastrointestinal complaints, headache, and life-threatening conditions such as hypertensive crisis and serotonin syndrome. MAOIs do not cause prolongation of the QT interval or torsades de pointes.

C) INCORRECT:

Bupropion can cause tachycardia and palpitations and, in the case of overdose, can result in prolongation of the QTc interval. However, it is not known to cause torsades de pointes. Other adverse effects of bupropion include agitation, weight loss, neuropsychiatric symptoms (e.g., depression, mania, psychosis, and paranoia), and serotonin syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

SSRIs such as sertraline do not typically cause prolongation of the QT interval or torsades de pointes. Adverse effects of SSRIs include sexual disorders (e.g., anorgasmia, erectile or ejaculatory dysfunction, decreased libido), diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, headache, and serotonin syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) such as amitriptyline block the fast sodium channels in the myocardium. This effect causes decreased cardiac conduction velocity, which results in a prolonged QT interval that predisposes to torsades de pointes. Other drugs that can predispose to torsades de pointes include class IA and class III antiarrhythmics (e..g, quinidine, sotalol, dofetilide), antibiotics (e.g., erythromycin, ciprofloxacin), and antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol).

Torsades de pointes increases the risk of ventricular fibrillation and sudden cardiac death. Treatment with sodium bicarbonate increases serum pH, decreases TCA binding to sodium channels, and shortens the QRS complex.
Image Description:

Monomorphic VT: QRS morphology is similar throughout, indicating a single arrhythmogenic focus.

Polymorphic VT: QRS morphology varies, indicating multiple arrhythmogenic foci.

Torsades de pointes is a subtype of polymorphic VT occurring in patients with QT prolongation, in which the QRS complexes appear to twist around the isoelectric line.
questions.hint: Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with a sinusoidal waveform on ECG is characteristic of torsades de pointes, which typically occurs secondary to prolongation of the QTc interval. One specific class of antidepressants can prolong the QTc interval.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a suicide attempt. His wife found him on the bathroom floor with an empty bottle of medication next to him. He has a history of major depressive disorder. His only medication is nortriptyline. His pulse is 127/min and blood pressure is 90/61 mm Hg. Examination shows dilated pupils and dry skin. The abdomen is distended and there is dullness on percussion in the suprapubic region. An ECG shows tachycardia and a QRS complex width of 130 ms. In addition to intravenous fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Because TCAs have anticholinergic properties, administering anticholinergic atropine to this patient with suspected nortriptyline toxicity would worsen the symptoms caused by cholinergic blockade (urinary retention, tachycardia, bowel distention, dry skin). Instead, atropine is an antidote used in organophosphate poisoning, which results in parasympathetic hyperstimulation that manifests as sweating, vomiting, diarrhea, miosis, bradycardia, bronchospasm.

B) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is the antidote for opioid overdose. Signs of opioid overdose include decreased respiratory rate, shallow breathing, bradycardia, and miosis, which is not consistent with this patient's presentation. Naloxone causes tachycardia and would worsen this patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Cyproheptadine has no role in the management of TCA toxicity but is an antidote for serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome manifests with autonomic hyperactivity (nausea, sweating, tremors, tachycardia, hypertension), neuromuscular hyperactivity (hyperreflexia, impaired gait), mental status changes (disorientation to place and time), and hyperthermia in patients taking serotonergic drugs (e.g., citalopram, venlafaxine). Dry skin and hypotension, as seen here, are not features of serotonin syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

TCAs block the fast sodium channels in the myocardium, which decreases cardiac conduction velocity, resulting in prolonged QRS complexes (≥ 100 ms) and cardiac arrhythmias. In cases of TCA overdose involving arrhythmias, IV sodium bicarbonate is indicated to alkalinize plasma so that protein binding of TCAs (weak bases) prevents the drug from binding to the fast sodium channels. Additionally, sodium bicarbonate increases extracellular sodium concentration, which makes the remaining fast sodium channels more active.

In patients with TCA overdose, the duration of QRS complexes correlates with the likelihood of developing ventricular arrhythmias and seizures and can, therefore, be used as an indicator of the severity of intoxication.

E) INCORRECT:

Lorazepam, a benzodiazepine, is the treatment of choice for TCA-induced seizures. There is no role of prophylactic administration of lorazepam in patients with TCA toxicity who are not having a seizure.
questions.hint: This patient presents with prolonged QRS complexes (≥ 100 ms), tachycardia, hypotension, mydriasis, dry skin, and urinary retention. These symptoms are suggestive of an overdose of nortriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA).

questions.text: A previously healthy 32-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-month history of fatigue and daytime sleepiness. He works as an accountant and cannot concentrate at work anymore. He also has depressed mood and no longer takes pleasure in activities he used to enjoy, such as playing tennis with his friends. He has decreased appetite and has had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss during the past 2 months. He does not have suicidal ideation. He is diagnosed with major depressive disorder and treatment with paroxetine is begun. The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tricyclic antidepressants have anticholinergic effects, which can induce tachycardia, arrhythmia, intestinal ileus, and a decrease in bladder detrusor muscle contraction that can lead to urinary retention. However, anticholinergic effects are not a common side effect of SSRIs like paroxetine.

B) INCORRECT:

Serotonin syndrome is a very rare side effect of monotherapy with SSRIs. Instead, this syndrome is more likely to occur with simultaneous use of two or more serotonergic medications (e.g., MAO inhibitor + SSRI). Serotonin syndrome can also occur when switching the medication regimen from one serotonergic drug class to another serotonergic drug class (e.g., from MAO inhibitor to SSRI). For that reason, the first drug should be tapered or even stopped for some days before introducing the new agent.

C) INCORRECT:

While some studies have shown that antidepressants can increase the risk of suicide in patients under 24 years of age with pre-existing suicidal ideation in the first weeks of treatment, there is no evidence that SSRIs or tricyclic antidepressants increase suicidality in nonsuicidal individuals of this patient's age group. This rather rare side effect is assumed to be caused by the sequential onset of these drug's effects: While SSRIs can increase a patient's motivation to initiate and perform self-directed activities (including self-harming behavior) already shortly after initiating treatment, the onset of the mood-lifting effects can be delayed by 2–4 weeks. Since this patient is 32 years old and is not suicidal, another side effect should be considered.

D) CORRECT:

Up to half of patients taking SSRIs experience sexual dysfunction, including decreased libido, delayed ejaculation, or anorgasmia. In addition, SSRIs may impair male fertility. SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction can remit spontaneously within 2–8 weeks. However, if sexual dysfunction persists, decreasing the SSRI dose or switching to a non-SSRI antidepressant (e.g., bupropion, mirtazapine) may be indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypertensive crisis is a potential side effect of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAO inhibitors) in combination with the consumption of tyramine-containing products (e.g., aged cheese, smoked meat, wine). Since tyramine is metabolized by MAO, the inhibition of MAO can lead to accumulation of tyramine. Excess tyramine can induce elevated norepinephrine release. This leads to the activation of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, causing vasoconstriction and subsequent hypertension. Hypertensive crisis is not an expected adverse effect of treatment with SSRIs.
questions.hint: This patient meets criteria for major depressive disorder, as evidenced by his depressed mood, anhedonia, fatigue, poor concentration, sleep disturbances, decreased appetite, and weight loss. Paroxetine belongs to the class of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI), the first-line treatment for major depressive disorder.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a severe, throbbing, occipital headache for 2 hours. She also reports nausea, photophobia, and chest tightness. The symptoms developed shortly after she had a snack consisting of salami and some dried fruits at a wine tasting event. The patient has recurrent migraine headaches and depression, for which she takes medication daily. She is mildly distressed, diaphoretic, and her face is flushed. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9 F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 190/128 mmHg. Deep-tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by a side effect of which of the following medications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paroxetine, an SSRI, is used as first-line treatment for major depressive disorder. Patients taking SSRIs may develop serotonin syndrome, which can also present with hypertension, diaphoresis, and GI disturbances. However, serotonin syndrome is usually characterized by altered mental state, hyperthermia, hyperreflexia, and myoclonus, none of which are seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Tranylcypromine, a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI), is typically reserved for treatment-resistant or atypical major depressive disorder given its severe side effect profile and numerous drug interactions. Monoamine oxidase breaks down excess tyramine in the body. Since MAOIs block this enzyme, the consumption of tyramine-rich foods (e.g., red wine, certain nuts, aged cheeses or meats, dried fruits) leads to an accumulation of tyramine. This, in turn, leads to a release of norepinephrine that can provoke a hypertensive crisis, as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Almotriptan, a 5-HT1 receptor agonist, is typically used as an abortive therapy for migraine headache. It can cause vasoconstriction and transient increase in blood pressure but would be unlikely to cause hypertensive crisis, as seen with this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Topiramate, an anticonvulsant, can be used as a prophylactic treatment for migraine headache. Its side effect profile includes somnolence, glaucoma, weight loss, and kidney stones but not hypertensive crisis, as seen in this patient, making this an unlikely source of the symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Doxepin, a tricyclic antidepressant, can be used for the treatment of depression and migraine prophylaxis. Its side effects include anticholinergic effects (tachycardia, hypotension), sedation, and delirium. Furthermore, it is associated with increased risk of developing serotonin syndrome, which can present with hypertension, diaphoresis, and GI disturbances. However, serotonin syndrome is usually characterized by altered mental status, hyperthermia, hyperreflexia, and myoclonus, none of which are seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Ingestion of tyramine-rich food (e.g., cured meats, dried fruits, red wine) in conjunction with this medication can lead to hypertensive crisis.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes, congestive heart failure, and depression is hospitalized with volume overload and cellulitis. She is started on linezolid and levofloxacin for the cellulitis and furosemide for the volume overload. Her other medications from home (citalopram, lisinopril, and metformin) are continued. Three days later, she becomes confused and has diffuse muscular rigidity. Her temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F) and her blood pressure is 190/110 mm Hg. Which of this patient's medications is most likely responsible for her clinical change?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Furosemide, levofloxacin, lisinopril, and metformin can all cause drug fever or hypersensitivity, but they do not cause the autonomic or neuromuscular findings associated with serotonin syndrome, such as hypertension or muscular rigidity. In addition to causing drug fever or hypersensitivity, these medicines can affect patients in other ways. Excessive doses of lisinopril and furosemide usually cause hypotension, not hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Furosemide, levofloxacin, lisinopril, and metformin can all cause drug fever or hypersensitivity, but they do not cause the autonomic or neuromuscular findings associated with serotonin syndrome, such as hypertension or muscular rigidity. In addition to causing drug fever or hypersensitivity, metformin can exacerbate lactic acidosis and is therefore generally discontinued among hospitalized patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Furosemide, levofloxacin, lisinopril, and metformin can all cause drug fever or hypersensitivity, but they do not cause the autonomic or neuromuscular findings associated with serotonin syndrome, such as hypertension or muscular rigidity. In addition to causing drug fever or hypersensitivity, excessive doses of lisinopril usually cause hypotension, not hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Furosemide, levofloxacin, lisinopril, and metformin can all cause drug fever or hypersensitivity, but they do not cause the autonomic or neuromuscular findings associated with serotonin syndrome, such as hypertension or muscular rigidity. In addition to causing drug fever or hypersensitivity, levofloxacin can induce altered mental status (delirium, agitation), most commonly in older adults.

E) CORRECT:

Linezolid is a reversible, nonselective monoamine oxidase inhibitor. Coadministering it with an SSRI can precipitate serotonin syndrome. Treatment requires immediate discontinuation of the offending agent.

The Food and Drug Administration has issued a drug-safety communication warning against the use of linezolid in patients taking SSRIs, except for patients with nosocomial infections or in urgent circumstances. If possible, it is best to use an alternative antibiotic because rapid discontinuation of an SSRI can be associated with severe withdrawal symptoms. In addition, the parent drug and active metabolites of some SSRIs have long elimination half-lives that, in some cases, require several weeks before linezolid can be safely initiated.

Key learning point: The antibiotic that can precipitate serotonin syndrome when given to patients taking selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors is linezolid.
questions.hint: This patient's altered mental status (confusion or agitation), autonomic dysfunction (fever, tachycardia, diarrhea, or diaphoresis), and neuromuscular abnormalities (tremor, clonus, or hypertonicity) are strongly suggestive of serotonin syndrome, a potentially life-threatening reaction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the office because of a 9-month history of sleep disturbances and restlessness. He has difficulty falling asleep and wakes up at least 3 times per night. He worries about paying his bills, failing law school, and disappointing his parents. He can no longer concentrate in class and failed his last exam. He feels on edge most days and avoids socializing with his classmates because he is afraid that he will fail further exams. He worries that he has an underlying medical condition that is causing his symptoms. Previous diagnostic evaluations were unremarkable. In addition to psychotherapy, treatment with which of the following drugs is most appropriate in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Duloxetine, a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), is considered a first-line treatment option for GAD. SNRIs are effective anxiolytics with no potential for dependence, and they have a more favorable side-effect profile than second and third-line options. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are also an alternative first-line drug. Although symptoms generally begin to improve within 4–6 weeks of initiating SNRIs/SSRIs, some patients may experience agitation and insomnia during this time period. A 4–6 week course of a sedating antihistamine, gabapentin, or a benzodiazepine (in those without a history of substance use disorder) may be considered in these patients. Second-line therapies for GAD include augmentation of an SNRI/SSRI with buspirone or gabapentin (if there was a partial initial response to first-line treatment) or switching to a different SNRI/SSRI (if there was no response to initial treatment).

Key learning point: First-line pharmacotherapy for generalized anxiety disorder includes SSRIs and SNRIs such as duloxetine, which are effective and have a favorable side-effect profile compared to other options.

B) INCORRECT:

Mirtazapine is primarily used in the treatment of major depressive disorder, and possibly as a third-line treatment option in GAD. Mirtazapine causes sedation, which can be beneficial in patients with insomnia. However, mirtazapine is not as effective as first-line treatment options and has numerous other adverse effects (e.g., weight gain, dry mouth, excessive sedation) that often lead to patients discontinuing it.

C) INCORRECT:

Propranolol can be used as an adjunctive medication in the primary treatment of panic disorder, which typically presents with recurrent, unexpected panic attacks in which the patient experiences intense episodes of fear and discomfort, overstimulation of the sympathetic system (e.g., sweating, palpitations), and concern for future attacks. This patient's symptoms, however, are not consistent with panic disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Buspirone can be used in the treatment of GAD. However, it is considered a second-line treatment option and can also be used as an augmenting agent in patients who have only a partial response to first-line treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Lorazepam, a benzodiazepine, can be used as an adjunctive medication in the treatment of GAD. While effective in improving symptoms such as agitation and insomnia in the short term, benzodiazepines should never be used in long-term management because of their high potential for addiction and negative side-effect profile.
questions.hint: Prolonged anxiety (> 6 months) about various aspects of daily life (e.g., school, health, finances, family) that disrupts regular activities and functioning is suggestive of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the office because she feels depressed, has difficulty sleeping, has a poor appetite, and has low concentration for the past 3 months. During this time, she has also had low energy and lost interest in playing the guitar. The patient also repeatedly engages in binge eating and purging behavior, for which she has been referred to therapy. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Treatment of her current symptoms with which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) used as a first-line treatment for major depressive disorder. Combinations of fluoxetine and MAOIs increase the risk of serotonin syndrome; therefore, concomitant use of these drugs is contraindicated. Moreover, SSRIs are frequently associated with sexual dysfunction (e.g., decreased libido, difficulty achieving erection, anorgasmia) and are thus not preferred in patients with pre-existing sexual impairment. Fluoxetine is not, however, associated with seizure generation in patients with bulimia nervosa and would be an appropriate treatment option in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Trazodone is a serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitor (SARI) used in the treatment of major depressive disorder, particularly when associated with insomnia. Trazodone is contraindicated with concomitant MAOI use (including up to 2 weeks after discontinuation) because this combination increases the risk of serotonin syndrome. In addition, trazodone has been associated with priapism and should, therefore, be used with caution in patients who have risk factors for priapism such as patients with sickle cell disease or leukemia. However, trazodone is not known to increase the risk of seizures in bulimia patients. While trazodone would not be the treatment of choice in this patient, she does not have any contraindications to its use.

C) CORRECT:

Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant used as a second-line treatment for major depressive disorder that is also used in smoking cessation therapy. It selectively inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine, with a more pronounced effect on the dopaminergic system. The most severe side effect is a decreased seizure threshold; therefore, bupropion is contraindicated in patients with other seizure risk factors (e.g., anorexia/bulimia, epilepsy, alcohol withdrawal).

Other drugs that decrease seizure thresholds are penicillins (in the presence of renal failure), ciprofloxacin, imipenem, isoniazid, theophylline, opioids (e.g., tramadol), and psychostimulants (e.g., cocaine, amphetamines).

D) INCORRECT:

Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant used as a second-line treatment for major depressive disorder. Mirtazapine is contraindicated with concomitant MAOI use (including up to 2 weeks after discontinuation) because this combination increases the risk of serotonin syndrome. Furthermore, a side effect of mirtazapine is increased appetite and weight gain, which may not always be desirable in bulimia patients as it can decrease drug compliance. However, while mirtazapine would not be the treatment of choice in this patient, a history of bulimia nervosa is not a contraindication to its use.

E) INCORRECT:

Citalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) used as a first-line treatment for major depressive disorder. Citalopram is contraindicated with concomitant MAOI use (including up to 2 weeks after discontinuation) because this combination increases the risk of serotonin syndrome. However, citalopram is not known to increase the risk of seizures in bulimia patients and would be an appropriate treatment option in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient shows symptoms of major depressive disorder, with a depressed mood present for longer than 2 weeks, lack of energy, anhedonia (loss of interest), sleep disturbance, loss of appetite, and loss of concentration. However, the patient's comorbidity with bulimia nervosa (binge-purge behavior) increases the risk of seizures with the administration of one particular antidepressant.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the office because of depressed mood for 6 months. He cannot concentrate at work anymore. He experiences fatigue because he repeatedly wakes up at night and has difficulties falling asleep again. He reports no longer taking pleasure in activities he used to enjoy, such as going fishing with his son. He has decreased appetite and has had a weight loss of 5 kg (11 lb) over the past 6 months. He does not have suicidal ideation. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medication. He is diagnosed with major depressive disorder and a trial of sertraline is suggested. The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Postural hypotension is a potential side effect of tricyclic antidepressants (TCA), but not a common side effect of SSRIs. TCAs block alpha-1 receptors on the blood vessels, which can cause vasodilation, hypotension, and impaired baroreflexes.

B) INCORRECT:

Serotonin syndrome is a very rare side effect of monotherapy with SSRIs, as is the case in this patient. Instead, this syndrome is more likely to occur with simultaneous use of two or more serotonergic medications (e.g., MAO inhibitor and SSRI). Serotonin syndrome can also occur when switching the medication regimen from one serotonergic drug class to another serotonergic drug class (e.g., from MAO inhibitor to SSRI). For that reason, the first drug should be tapered or even stopped for some days before introducing the new agent.

C) CORRECT:

Up to half of the patients taking SSRIs experience sexual dysfunction, including delayed ejaculation and other conditions such as anorgasmia and decreased libido. SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction can remit spontaneously within 2–8 weeks. However, if sexual dysfunction persists, decreasing the SSRI dose (in patients who are on high doses and in remission), augmentation with sildenafil, or switching to a non-SSRI antidepressant that do not cause sexual dysfunction (e.g., bupropion, mirtazapine) may be indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

While some studies have shown that antidepressants can increase the risk of suicide in patients under 24 years of age with pre-existing (!) suicidal ideation in the first weeks of treatment, there is no evidence that SSRIs or tricyclic antidepressants increase suicidality in nonsuicidal individuals of this patient's age group. This rather rare side effect is assumed to be caused by the sequential onset of these drug's effects: while SSRIs can increase a patient's motivation to initiate and perform self-directed activities (including self-harming behavior) already shortly after initiating treatment, the onset of the mood-lifting effects can be delayed by 2–4 weeks. Since this patient is 58 years old and is not suicidal, another side effect should be considered.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypertensive crisis is a potential side effect of monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAO inhibitors) in combination with the consumption of tyramine-containing products (e.g., aged cheese, smoked meat, wine). Since tyramine is metabolized by MAO, the inhibition of MAO can lead to the accumulation of tyramine. Excess tyramine can induce elevated norepinephrine release. This leads to the activation of alpha-1 receptors, causing vasoconstriction and subsequent hypertension. Patients are therefore advised to follow a low-tyramine diet during therapy with MAO inhibitors.
questions.hint: This patient meets criteria for major depressive disorder, as evidenced by his depressed mood, anhedonia, fatigue, poor concentration, sleep disturbances, decreased appetite, and weight loss. Sertraline belongs to the class of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI), the first-line treatment for major depressive disorder.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes for a follow-up examination 3 months after beginning sertraline therapy for major depressive disorder. He takes the medication as prescribed and has started psychotherapy, but his mood has barely improved. The patient appears anxious and reports that he still feels sad and hopeless most of the time. He denies suicidal ideation. He is more tired than usual and has difficulty concentrating at work; he worries that he might soon lose his job. He is also concerned because he has continuously gained weight despite the initiation of sertraline. This patient will most likely benefit from switching to which of the following pharmacotherapies?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant that causes sedation. An antidepressant without a sedative effect is necessary for this patient with drowsiness, lethargy, and difficulty concentrating. Moreover, if trazodone is used as monotherapy for MDD, high doses of trazodone are needed for an antidepressant effect and are associated with an increased risk of other side effects (e.g., cardiotoxicity, hypertension, priapism). Trazodone is primarily used in low doses for the treatment of insomnia or as an augmentation agent for the treatment of MDD if the patient has insomnia as a predominant symptom.

B) CORRECT:

The preferred first-line treatment for MDD is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) such as sertraline. Response to the antidepressant is assessed 6–12 weeks after initiating treatment. If the patient has minimal response to the initial therapy or experiences significant adverse effects, the antidepressant should be replaced with a different one by cross-tapering. The class of antidepressants that should be prescribed as a replacement depends on the type of depressive symptoms (e.g., hypersomnia vs. hyposomnia, hyperphagia vs. anorexia, weight gain vs. weight loss) and the side effects from the initial drug (e.g., SSRIs can cause drowsiness, anorgasmia, and decreased libido). This patient has lethargy, difficulty concentrating, and weight gain, and would therefore benefit from switching to bupropion, an atypical antidepressant that has a stimulant effect and is associated with weight loss. Bupropion also does not cause sexual dysfunction.

If the patient has a partial response to the initial antidepressant with minimal adverse effects, then augmentation therapy with another medication (e.g., a different antidepressant, an atypical antipsychotic, lithium, liothyronine) or with psychotherapy should be considered. If the patient has a complete response to the initial antidepressant prescribed for the first onset of a major depressive episode, the drug is continued for another 6–12 months (continuation phase therapy) after which it can be gradually tapered off if the patient remains in remission. Therapy beyond this period (maintenance phase therapy) is considered for patients with a history of recurrent, long-lasting, and/or severe major depressive episodes.

C) INCORRECT:

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), such as imipramine, can cause sedation, but also have other significant side effects, including anticholinergic effects (e.g., urinary retention, dry mouth), and are only used in exceptional cases. Switching to an antidepressant with a better side effect profile would be more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

In cases where the patient has minimal response to sertraline, switching to another selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), such as paroxetine, can be helpful. However, this patient is experiencing drowsiness, a possible side effect of all SSRIs. Moreover, paroxetine is an SSRI that can cause weight gain. For this patient, switching to another antidepressant class with a more favorable side effect profile is appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

The anxiolytic buspirone is used primarily for the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder. There is no evidence to support the use of buspirone as either a monotherapy or augmentation agent in the treatment of MDD.
questions.hint: This patient with major depressive disorder (MDD) shows continued symptoms of depression (e.g., depressed mood, feelings of worthlessness, lethargy, difficulty concentrating, weight gain) and drowsiness (a possible side effect of sertraline) after 3 months of antidepressant therapy. Switching to a different antidepressant that can facilitate weight loss and that is less likely to cause drowsiness should be considered.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman with a history of major depressive disorder presents 6 months after starting fluoxetine. She reports that her mood, concentration, sleep, and appetite have all improved but that her libido diminished shortly after beginning fluoxetine and she can no longer achieve an orgasm. She has no history of hypertension or seizure disorders. She is pleased with the response to fluoxetine and is reluctant to switch antidepressants or change the dose. She asks how the sexual side effects can be treated. Which one of the following strategies is most appropriate for treating this patient’s symptoms of sexual dysfunction?

choices.text: Wait 3 to 6 more months before making a medication change

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Unfortunately, SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction is often a persistent adverse effect despite attempts to ameliorate it. Therefore, waiting longer without making a change is not likely to resolve the issue.

B) INCORRECT:

Quetiapine can be added to an antidepressant when there is only a partial response to the antidepressant. This patient has responded well to treatment so does not require augmentation. Quetiapine may also induce sexual dysfunction.

C) CORRECT:

Unfortunately, SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction is often a persistent adverse effect despite attempts to ameliorate it. Nonetheless, there are several strategies worth trying. These include lowering the SSRI dose, adding bupropion to the SSRI, or switching from the SSRI to bupropion. The choice from among these strategies should be individualized.

This patient has had relief of her depression symptoms with fluoxetine. Therefore, lowering the SSRI dose or switching to a different antidepressant is not likely to be her first choice.

Adding a second agent may be more suited to this patient’s situation. There is limited, mainly open-label evidence that bupropion can reverse SSRI-induced sexual adverse effects, even when the SSRI is continued. It may improve desire or other aspects of sexual functioning.

Key learning point: The most appropriate approach to treat depression in a patient who develops sexual dysfunction with the use of selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors is to use the medicine bupropion.

D) INCORRECT:

Duloxetine is associated with sexual dysfunction and would not typically be used in combination with fluoxetine because the two medications have a similar effect on sexual functioning.

E) INCORRECT:

Although estrogen clearly has an effect on mood and overall sense of well-being, it is not an effective treatment for depression per se and is not an appropriate choice in this patient‘s treatment.
questions.hint: In both men and women, the use of selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) is associated with reduced libido, problems with genital arousal, and delayed or absent orgasm. Although the mechanism for this effect remains unknown, serotonin’s dampening effect on nitric oxide and dopamine may be a factor.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for a severe throbbing headache and nausea for 3 hours. Prior to onset of symptoms, she had red wine and, shortly after, a snack consisting of salami and some dried fruits. The patient has recurrent migraine headaches and depression, for which she takes medication daily. She is mildly distressed, diaphoretic, and her face is flushed. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 195/130 mm Hg. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by a side effect of which of the following medications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant, can be used for the treatment of depression and migraine prophylaxis. Its side effects include anticholinergic effects (tachycardia, flushed skin), sedation, and delirium. Furthermore, it is associated with an increased risk of developing serotonin syndrome, which can present with hypertension, diaphoresis, and gastrointestinal disturbances. However, serotonin syndrome is usually characterized by altered mental state, hyperthermia, hyperreflexia, and myoclonus, none of which are seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Sumatriptan, a 5-HT1 receptor agonist, is typically used as an abortive therapy for migraine headaches. It can cause vasoconstriction and a transient increase in blood pressure but would be unlikely to cause a hypertensive crisis, as seen with this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) such as phenelzine are typically reserved for treatment-resistant or atypical major depressive disorder as they have a severe side-effect profile and numerous drug interactions. As MAOIs inhibit monoamine oxidase, the consumption of tyramine-rich foods (e.g., red wine, certain nuts, aged cheeses, cured meats, dried fruits) can lead to an accumulation of tyramine. This, in turn, results in a release of norepinephrine, which can induce a hypertensive crisis.

D) INCORRECT:

Topiramate, an anticonvulsant, can be used as a prophylactic treatment for migraine headache. Its side effect profile includes somnolence, glaucoma, weight loss, and kidney stones, but not hypertensive crisis, as seen in this patient, making this an unlikely source of the symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Sertraline, an SSRI, is used as first-line treatment for major depressive disorder. Patients taking SSRIs may develop serotonin syndrome, which can also present with hypertension, diaphoresis, and gastrointestinal disturbances. However, serotonin syndrome is usually characterized by altered mental state, hyperthermia, hyperreflexia, and myoclonus, none of which are seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient developed a hypertensive crisis after recent ingestion of foods rich in tyramine (e.g., cured meats, dried fruits, red wine).

questions.text: A previously healthy 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after the sudden onset of nausea, vomiting, and confusion. She was found with an open bottle of her mother's antidepressive medication. On arrival, the patient is obtunded. Temperature is 39.9°C (103.8°F), pulse is 165/min, respirations are 11/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. Examination shows dilated pupils, dry lips, flushed skin, and decreased bowel sounds. Electrocardiography shows sinus tachycardia and a widened QRS complex (130 ms). Supportive therapy with intravenous fluids and supplemental oxygen is begun. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucagon is an antidote for beta-blocker poisoning, which can cause altered mental status and hypotension, both of which are seen here. Characteristic ECG features of beta-blocker toxicity are bradycardia (β1 receptor blockade prevents the reflex tachycardia associated with hypotension) and a wide PR interval (due to a first-degree AV block); tachycardia and wide QRS complex would not be expected. Other features seen in this patient, e.g., mydriasis, hyperthermia, and flushed skin (i.e., anticholinergic effects), cannot be explained by beta-blocker poisoning. Glucagon administration is not recommended in the management of patients with TCA intoxication, as it would worsen the tachycardia.

B) INCORRECT:

Physostigmine can be used as an antidote in severe anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., atropine overdose). While this patient has symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., dry skin), additional findings suggest TCA intoxication. Physostigmine is contraindicated in patients with TCA intoxication because it is associated with an increased risk of cardiac arrest and seizures.

C) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is the antidote for acetaminophen poisoning, which can manifest with nausea, vomiting, and, in the case of acute liver failure, altered mental status. In acetaminophen poisoning, hepatic toxicity typically becomes symptomatic within 24 hours of ingestion and manifests with additional symptoms such as right upper quadrant pain and jaundice. The anticholinergic features seen in this patient (e.g., mydriasis, hyperthermia, flushed skin, arrhythmia) cannot be explained by acetaminophen poisoning. NAC is not used in the treatment of TCA toxicity.

D) CORRECT:

TCAs block the fast sodium channels in the myocardium, which decreases cardiac conduction velocity, resulting in prolonged QRS complexes and cardiac arrhythmias. In cases of TCA overdose involving ventricular arrhythmias or QRS complexes > 100 ms, IV sodium bicarbonate is indicated to alkalinize plasma so that protein binding of TCAs (weak bases) can prevent the drug from binding to the fast sodium channels. Additionally, sodium bicarbonate increases the extracellular sodium concentration, which makes the remaining fast sodium channels more active. In patients with TCA overdose, the duration of QRS complexes correlates with the likelihood of developing ventricular arrhythmias and seizures and can, therefore, be used as an indicator of the severity of intoxication. In patients presenting within 2 hours of TCA ingestion, gastric decontamination with activated charcoal can be performed if the airway is established and circulation is secured.

Antiarrhythmics that are typically used in the management of ventricular tachycardia (e.g., procainamide, amiodarone) are contraindicated in TCA overdose because of the risk of worsening sodium channel blockade and/or QTc prolongation.

E) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is the antidote for opioid intoxication. Although this patient has some features of opioid intoxication (respiratory depression, decreased bowel sounds, altered mental status, hypotension), she has ingested TCAs, not opioids. Additionally, the patient presents with mydriasis instead of miosis, which would be the expected finding in opioid intoxication. Hyperthermia and wide QRS complexes on ECG cannot be explained by opioid toxicity. Naloxone causes tachycardia and would worsen this patient's symptoms.
questions.hint: This girl presents with features of anticholinergic toxicity (hyperthermia, pupillary dilation, flushed skin, decreased bowel sounds, sinus tachycardia), antihistaminic effects (sedation), α1 receptor inhibition (hypotension), and inhibition of cardiac fast sodium channels (QRS widening), which together strongly suggest tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) intoxication.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of feeling consistently sad, having little interest in daily activities, and lacking energy. He has a 3-year history of focal epilepsy and is on lamotrigine. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and is frustrated by multiple failed quit attempts. Physical examination shows a calm but withdrawn affect. His neurological exam is unchanged from baseline. He requests medication to help both his low mood and smoking habit.
Which of the following medications is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Varenicline, a partial agonist at α4β2 nicotinic receptors, aids smoking cessation by reducing cravings and withdrawal symptoms. It does not lower the seizure threshold and is not contraindicated in patients with stable depressive symptoms or epilepsy.

B) INCORRECT:

Sertraline, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), is used for major depressive disorder and does not significantly lower the seizure threshold. It is safe for patients with epilepsy and those on lamotrigine, as it does not interfere with seizure control.

C) CORRECT:

Bupropion inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine, aiding in depression management and smoking cessation. However, it is contraindicated in patients with seizure disorders, such as epilepsy, due to its proconvulsant effect, which lowers the seizure threshold. This risk persists even in well-controlled epilepsy, as bupropion increases neuronal excitability, potentially triggering seizures. Clinical guidelines advise against its use in individuals with a history of seizures to maintain seizure control.

Key learning point: Bupropion is contraindicated in patients with a history of seizures or epilepsy due to its potential to lower the seizure threshold.

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotine patches provide a steady nicotine level to minimize withdrawal symptoms in smoking cessation. They do not lower the seizure threshold and have no significant interactions with lamotrigine, making them safe for patients with epilepsy and mood disturbances.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with bulimia nervosa wants to quit smoking and requests medication support. Which medication most increases his seizure risk?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant used for smoking cessation that acts as a norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake inhibitor. It is known to lower the seizure threshold, particularly in patients with bulimia nervosa, who often have electrolyte imbalances that further increase seizure risk. The combination of bupropion's pharmacologic effects and the physiological disturbances in bulimia necessitates caution due to the heightened seizure risk in this population.

Key learning point: Bupropion is associated with an increased risk of seizures, which is a significant side effect to consider when prescribing it for smoking cessation.

B) INCORRECT:

Varenicline is a selective partial agonist at α4β2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, effective in smoking cessation. It is associated with side effects like nausea and vivid dreams but does not significantly lower the seizure threshold, even in patients with conditions like bulimia nervosa.

C) INCORRECT:

The nicotine patch provides controlled nicotine delivery to alleviate withdrawal symptoms without causing plasma concentration peaks that could lead to neurologic excitability. It does not lower the seizure threshold, making it a safer option for patients with bulimia nervosa.

D) INCORRECT:

Nortriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant, has a modest tendency to lower the seizure threshold at therapeutic doses. While it can promote seizures in overdose or with other proconvulsant factors, its seizure risk is less concerning than that of bupropion in patients with bulimia nervosa.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man with depression started taking a new medication 2 weeks ago. He now complains of insomnia, anxiety, and restlessness. What mechanism best explains these new symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Augmented dopamine release is characteristic of stimulant medications, not standard antidepressants. Such release can cause euphoria or behavioral changes, but insomnia, anxiety, and restlessness are more associated with increased serotonergic or noradrenergic activity.

B) CORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) inhibit the serotonin transporter, increasing serotonin concentration at synaptic junctions. This leads to enhanced stimulation of postsynaptic serotonin receptors. Initially, this overstimulation can manifest as insomnia, anxiety, and restlessness before receptor desensitization occurs. These side effects are common shortly after starting SSRI therapy due to the impact on neural circuits involved in mood and arousal.

Key learning point: Selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) can cause side effects such as insomnia, anxiety, and restlessness due to increased serotonin levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Blockade of histamine (H1) receptors typically causes sedation and drowsiness, as histamine promotes wakefulness. Antihistaminic activity usually results in somnolence, not insomnia, anxiety, or restlessness.

D) INCORRECT:

Upregulated GABAergic activity enhances inhibitory neurotransmission, leading to sedative and anxiolytic effects. Medications increasing GABA signaling typically reduce anxiety and promote sleep, contrasting with the insomnia and anxiety observed here.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man with major depressive disorder presents with constipation, dry mouth, and occasional blurry vision. He has been taking a tricyclic antidepressant for four weeks. He denies changes in diet or fluid intake. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and diminished bowel sounds. Laboratory results show no significant findings.
Which underlying mechanism most likely explains his recent symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of norepinephrine reuptake by tricyclic antidepressants increases norepinephrine levels, potentially causing tachycardia or hypertension. However, it does not cause constipation, dry mouth, or blurry vision, which are due to anticholinergic effects from muscarinic receptor blockade.

B) INCORRECT:

Histamine H₁ receptor blockade by tricyclic antidepressants is associated with sedation and weight gain, not with constipation, dry mouth, or blurry vision. These symptoms result from muscarinic receptor blockade, not H₁ receptor effects.

C) INCORRECT:

Tricyclic antidepressants can block alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, leading to vasodilation and orthostatic hypotension. However, this does not explain the patient's symptoms of constipation, dry mouth, and blurry vision, which are due to anticholinergic effects, not vascular changes.

D) CORRECT:

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) block muscarinic cholinergic receptors, leading to anticholinergic side effects. This blockade reduces parasympathetic activity, causing decreased gastrointestinal motility (constipation), reduced salivary secretion (dry mouth), and impaired ocular accommodation (blurry vision). These symptoms are characteristic of the anticholinergic effects associated with TCAs.

Key learning point: Tricyclic antidepressants are known to cause constipation due to their anticholinergic effects, which reduce gastrointestinal motility.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 4-month history of generalized fatigue and difficulty concentrating. He reports loss of interest in his hobbies and has stopped attending family events. On mental status examination, he has psychomotor retardation, a flat affect, and some evidence of suicidal ideation. His speech is slow and monotone. You initiate treatment with fluoxetine. At follow-up one month later, he reports significant improvement in motivation and mood, but now experiences delayed ejaculation and occasional anorgasmia. You decide to switch his medication. Which one of the following medications is most appropriate to prescribe?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Citalopram is, like fluoxetine, an SSRI that may, therefore, cause sexual dysfunction. Hence, it is not the right treatment choice for this patient. Other side effects of SSRIs such as citalopram include nausea, SIADH, and serotonin syndrome (when used with other serotonergic agents).

B) CORRECT:

Bupropion, which inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine, is an atypical antidepressant without sexual side effects and therefore a viable alternative for patients with MDD who experience sexual dysfunction due to SSRIs. Side effects of bupropion include reduction of the seizure threshold, tachycardia, insomnia, and headache. Bupropion is also used to treat tobacco dependence.

Mirtazapine, which increases the release of norepinephrine and serotonin by blocking the alpha-2 adrenergic receptor, is another atypical antidepressant that does not cause sexual dysfunction and can be used in patients with insomnia or anorexia.

Key learning point: Bupropion is an effective antidepressant alternative for patients experiencing SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction, as it does not commonly cause sexual side effects.

C) INCORRECT:

Trazodone is a 5-HT2 serotonin antagonist that is sometimes used as an adjunct to other antidepressants for the treatment of insomnia associated with depression. However, it is not indicated as monotherapy for major depressive disorder and therefore is not the right medication for this patient. Trazodone is not associated with sexual dysfunction, but priapism, orthostatic hypotension, and sedation are known side effects.

D) INCORRECT:

Venlafaxine is a selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor that is used for the treatment of major depressive disorder and generalized anxiety disorder. It has a similar side effect profile as SSRIs, including sexual dysfunction, nausea, dry mouth, headache, and serotonin syndrome (when used with other serotonergic agents). Hence, it is not the right medication choice for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOI) such as tranylcypromine can be used for treatment-refractory depression with atypical features (e.g., mood reactivity, hypersomnia, hyperphagia, leaden paralysis, interpersonal rejection sensitivity). MAOIs are not used as first- or even second-line agents to treat MDD without atypical features due to side effects such as drug interactions and hypertensive crisis following ingestion of tyramine-rich food (e.g., aged cheese).
questions.hint: This patient with fatigue, anhedonia, flat affect, suicidal ideation, and psychomotor retardation has major depressive disorder (MDD). Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as fluoxetine, are the first-line therapy for MDD, but sexual disorders (anorgasmia, erectile or ejaculatory dysfunction, decreased libido) are a known side effect of this agent group.

questions.text: You are seeing a 60-year-old man in the emergency department who presents with a persistent, painful erection that has lasted for 5 hours. His medical history includes osteoarthritis, insomnia, social anxiety disorder, gout, type 2 diabetes mellitus, major depressive disorder, and hypertension. He reports drinking one beer daily and using marijuana on weekends. His medications are propranolol, citalopram, trazodone, rasburicase, metformin, glyburide, lisinopril, and occasional ibuprofen. On examination, he has a rigid erection without evidence of trauma, penile discharge, injection, or prosthesis. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Marijuana use is not associated with priapism.

B) INCORRECT:

Citalopram, an SSRI, can cause sexual dysfunction such as erectile dysfunction, reduced libido, and anorgasmia. Citalopram does not, however, cause priapism at therapeutic dosage levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is a beta-blocker and therefore results in peripheral vasoconstriction. Vasoconstriction would cause erectile dysfunction rather than priapism. Antihypertensive drugs that are associated with priapism are alpha-1 receptor blockers such as prazosin.

D) CORRECT:

Priapism is a potential side effect of trazodone. The exact pathomechanism of trazodone-induced priapism is not fully understood but is most likely linked to the drug's alpha-1 receptor antagonism, which can lead to smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation. Low-flow priapism (LFP), which this patient has, is caused by inadequate venous outflow from the corpus cavernosum and results in painful penile ischemia and a rigid erection.
